title: 108_hr5319
content: The Act titled "Renewable Energy Financing Incentive Act of 2004" allows for nonrecognition of gain from the sale of real property upon subsequent purchase of renewable energy property under section 1046 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Act allows for nonrecognition of gain from the sale of real property if the seller acquires renewable energy property within the replacement period. No gain shall result to the taxpayer from the sale of renewable energy property, except as provided in subsections (b) and (e). Gain resulting from the sale is recognized when the price exceeds the cost of the property acquired. The gain recognized from the sale of renewable energy property is subject to certain rules and definitions. Renewable energy property refers to facilities in the US using renewable energy sources for electricity generation or fuel production. Special rules apply to stock and interests in partnerships. The gain from selling renewable energy property is subject to specific rules. Renewable energy property includes facilities in the US using renewable sources for electricity or fuel. Special rules apply to partnerships and stock in corporations focused on renewable energy. The gain from selling renewable energy property is subject to specific rules. Stock in a corporation primarily owning or operating renewable energy property is treated as such property. Rules similar to those for partnerships apply to cooperatives subject to specific tax codes. The replacement period is a 2-year period after the sale. The replacement period for real property sale is a 2-year period after the sale, and any property received must be identified within 180 days. For tax purposes, any property not identified within 180 days after transferring relinquished property is not considered like-kind. The basis of renewable energy property is the same as exchanged property, adjusted for money received and gains or losses recognized. Recapture rules apply. The basis of renewable energy property is the same as exchanged property, adjusted for money received and gains or losses recognized. Recapture rules apply if a taxpayer disposes of renewable energy property. The gain not recognized under subsection (a) for acquiring renewable energy property is not taken into account in certain dispositions, such as after the taxpayer's death or in a compulsory conversion. The statute of limitations applies to gains realized on the sale or exchange of renewable energy property if an election under subsection (a) is in effect. The statute of limitations for assessing deficiencies on gains from the sale or exchange of renewable energy property is extended to 3 years from the date the taxpayer notifies the Secretary of the cost of purchasing such property. The statute of limitations for assessing deficiencies on gains from the sale or exchange of renewable energy property is extended to 3 years from the date the taxpayer notifies the Secretary of the cost of purchasing such property. This allows for assessment of deficiencies in cases where the taxpayer fails to purchase renewable energy property within the replacement period. This allows for assessment of deficiencies in cases where the taxpayer fails to purchase renewable energy property within the replacement period. Additionally, amendments are made to Section 1016(a) of the Code regarding property acquisitions resulting in nonrecognition of gain. A new paragraph is added at the end, relating to the acquisition of property under section 1046. Amendments made to Section 1016(a) of the Code allow for nonrecognition of gain from the sale of real property upon subsequent purchase of renewable energy property. Effective after December 31, 2004.
